messageBody:
I'd also have to agree that the TestNG style is more elegant. The
JUnit form is more idiomatic, so the first time a programmer sees it,
it requires explanation. If you've been using TestNG (and thus are
comfortable with annotations in the first place),
@Test(expected=XException.class) is pretty obvious.

But I still prefer the JUnit form. First, I strive to have my tests
read as good examples of what client code might look like. In fact, I
often try to copy and paste test code into production use.

Second, in most cases I find that asserting solely on an exception
type is insufficient. Often (not always) I'm asserting some
postcondition in the catch block, or I'm asserting some nuance of the
exception object itself (message, typically).

Jeff

Quoting Stephen Smith <steve@...>:
> Cedric, I agree with Michael. The former example is a lot clearer and
> simpler to me, primarily for the reason that the structure of a
> try...catch block is so easy to understand. Even the most inexperienced
> Java developer can understand try...catch, whereas annotations can be a
> difficult subject to explain. Code to describe code? Using a
> JavaDoc-style syntax? Etc.
>
> I'd also suggest that the former example is more elegant, but we enter
> dangerously subjective territory at this point...
> --
> Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
